												I'll start by stating that The Witcher is a great game.A great game that has its good and bad.So let me review what I think is most important of any game ,the story,The gameplay and graphics.The witcher has a great story.The story starts really slow and dull until you reach the third chapter.By reaching the third chapter,things get really interesting.The problem is,you get dragged through 3 long boring chapters,with unnecessary main missions and some little odd ones.But in the end,the story stands out with its unique choices.The gamplay is the game's weakness.I say this with full confident due to alot of flows in the combat system,AI,boss   fights,difficulty, glitches and so more.The combat system is good idea the was executed badly due to random stunning you get even if you were away from enemies or they had no chance of hitting you,random bleeding,randomly beating an enemy with one hit even it is impossible,or even being forced to use a normal sword to what is clearly not a human enemy.The AI is bad,you may say it is justifiable for a game that came out in 2007 but i think they could have done better or at least updated it.The friends who company you die easily and completely useless.The enemy AI is odd and sometimes standing far away stops them from attacking you or simply running around them in circles.What really annoy me in some of the bosses is how scripted the fighting is.You could check The spider queen fight.It is unbelievable how scripted it was.The difficulty spike from easy to normal is ridiculous.I highly recommend playing it easy if you cant take dying from an OP enemy or a boss.Finally,the gliches.Three are alot of them.Sometimes you cant use any sign,even if you reloaded the game.Sometimes,by walking around a cretin area,you can avoid a main story fight!!some keys refuses to respond like your mouses right click or the saving button.Using a sigh has no effect on enemies who are close to you and this glitch can cause you troubles.I could take along times mentioning these glitches.The Witcher has a good graphics.The game obviously aged well.Even playing it without mods didn't make it old .Though you cant play it with SlI enabled without problems for some reason. In conclousion,The witcher is great game with alot of problems.I recommend it only in easy difficulty and for a really really patient gamer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2015
												Finally! After putting it off twice now, I've finally beat this long, incredible game. I know some people will say it wasn't too long but I tried to get as much out of it as I could. Anyway, on to the review, in this game you play as Geralt of Rivia. A witcher, which is basically a human that was trained from birth to hunt monsters and remove curses. Also, as part of the process, the witcher finally earns his name sake by completeing the trial of the grasses which is a long process involving taking mutagens which (if the human survives) transforms him into a mutant which gives him faster reflexes, better vision, and all that good stuff but at the cost of infertility. At the beginning you discover Geralt has lost his memory and is wounded but winds up on the steps of Khear Moren (sp?), basically the school and home for the Witchers. There he is nursed back to health by his fellow witchers and Triss Merigold, a sorcess and love interest. Just as Geralt is getting back on his feet, a group of thugs assisted by a couple powerful mages attack the castle. After a short battle, wherein you choose to help fight the monster that the mage brought with them or if you choose to go to the laboratory with Triss to stop them from stealing the Witchers secrets, you decide to split up to different corners of the world to find your groups lost secrets and to seek revenge on the group that attacked and so begins the game.The game is kind of hard to explain on paper, but I'll try my best. First off, combat isn't like in most games... when fighting anything you have to click on the target and Geralt will start attacking in a predetermined manner whereas during the attack your sword icon will light up between yellow and orange then go back to gray, during this time you have to click on the target again during the yellow/orange phase to follow through with a four step combo, the longer you prolong the combo the more damage that is done ending in a finisher stage which deals the most damage. Also, depending on your target, there is a lot of prep that goes into the fight before actually fighting. You have to consider the target, is it human or monster? If its human you must use your steel weapon or sword. If its monster, you must use your witchers silver sword, something you get in the second chapter of the game (there are 4 chapters and an epilogue). Then once you determine between human or monster, you must figure out if the target is a large target or small target because large targets require a strong attack stance and small targets require a small attack stance... usually. You can quickly switch between the three stances (the third being a group stance which is pretty good during almost all fights and covers both large and small targets) by pausing the game and selecting the stance, then resuming. Most of the time its all trial and error, if you attack a small framed guy and he seems to be dodging or parrying your attacks, switch to the strong and that'll drop him. Sometimes, if you get good enough and your skills improve, you can use most any attack stance on any size target with greater result (small/singular target + strong stance with improved skills = 2 hit kill). Then there is the oils and stones and such... some stones can imbue your swords with different effects for short periods of time, just apply before battle because he actually has to apply it. Same goes for oils, but the oils do different things, like making a target bleed more, causing more pain (causes the target to attack slower/move slower), and then theres the oils for different kinds of monsters. Like necrophage oil, causes more damage to ghosts. Insectoid oil, causes more damage to insect like monsters. And theres an oil that causes the blades to do more damage to dragons and such, the list goes on and that alone is complex.You also have magic that you learn by visiting stones scattered about the world. They give you powers like Aard, which is like force push from SW or just a strong burst of wind. Theres 5 total I believe but I only ever used Aard because when you level it up you can knock down multiple targets or even if you want to just quickly move through an area and theres one monster/human blocking the path you can sometimes stun the target which leaves them open for an instant melee kill. I also forgot to mention above that, just like the instant kills, fighting in general is very quick and visceral. Lots of blood flies around, wounds will appear, sometimes heads will roll but its a very satisfying part of the game. Just as with the magic and melee, as you progress through the game and level up, you gain points in the form of tokens which varies as you get higer level. These tokens are bronze, silver and gold and the skills you can buy follow the same form of scale being bronze is basic and gold is the best. As you progress through the game you will encounter tons of characters, often ones you can interact with. Some will give you missions, others will just say a few set things and continue about their business. As mentioned earlier, there is decision making opportunities that present themselves several times in the game and will always effect the game later down the road. So pick your decisions wisely and don't listen to the inner dialogue or other characters when they push you to pick a side... its totally possible (and apparently the prefered choice) to play the neutral part. The game can get tedious though... as one could imagine from my intro, this is the third time I've played it and actually the first time of successfully completing it. There are a few dull parts in the game, which I liken to the Song of Ice and Fire series from Martin, if you're familiar with them... when its boring its really dull but when it gets good its so damn good! Try to break up the dull parts by doing monster contracts which you can find at the local taverns, right outside on the billboard. Each chapter usually has like 6 different contracts posted and they'll always fetch decent money. But as for the story, probably one of the best games I've played and I really look forward to the next chapter in the series as the ending is left pretty open no matter what ending you get (there are 3 different kinds). I highly recommend this game just go in with an open mind and try to remember to think things through if you're stuck or try different strategies, because thats what this game is all about.

content:
21, 2013
												An amazing RPG that has just the right balance of old and new RPG mechanics. The only true flaw with the game is its numerous difficulty spikes, but in the grand scheme of things, this is forgiveable, as the rest of the game makes up for it. The combat blends together a tactical and action-focused approach, giving you a rush while retaining a D&D feel. The story is, in my opinion, highly original, with a monster slayer trying to cope with a changing world in which man can be a greater danger than beast. With this changing world, he too must change, learning to fight humans as well as monsters. In this ever-changing world, nothing is ever black and white.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2015
												This is a good narrative rpg, but a god awful video game. The combat is terrible, the character progression is terrible, the inventory management is terrible, the game's auto save system is completely sentient and makes its own damn rules, Act III comes with a hearty helping of cpu usage issues with a nice side of micro-stutter, oh and bad voice acting combined with robotic facial animations makes Geralt being hit on and getting laid constantly extremely awkward and uncomfortable. BUT, even with all that, play this game. The stories are well written and have numerous outcomes based entirely on the way you do things. Choices are rarely laid out in front of you and always have a significant impact later in the game.Recommendation: this game is everything that Bioware RPGs wishes they were, but the low budget and (probable)inexperience of CDProjektRed in 2007 hides the good behind multiple layers of clunk and awkward.Side Note: Assassin of Kings succeeds in virtually every area that this game fails, so it's an obvious choice over this game, but they allow you to import a save with all your choices, so I'd say The Witcher is worth suffering through to get the best experience out of the sequel, even if you hate its guts.

												An Amazing GemThis game is interesting from start to finish, with 6 chapters full of quests to do, all while u try to destroy SalamandraMy favorite chapters are 1,4,5 and final, chapter 2 seems a bit unfinished with multiple bugs making u stuck in the Storyline, plus being the bigger of them all it can make the game a bit tedious since the story in this chapter is rather doll and boring, chapter 3 is a bit better however only working toward the twistChapter 4 is sad in a emotional way and so interesting, chapter 5 and 6 are the ones that u rlly will loveAnd finnaly, Chapter 1 is my favorite overall, it rlly makes u think how a corrupted community can be punished or how does it affect our lives, how the sins of every single peb created such a monster capable of killing anyoneGameplay is nice, the whole meditation system is fun however a bit "limited" since u can only meditate while near a fireplace, and since with time the game gets harder it, it will be hard to keep making potions everytimeCombat is well not the strong point of this game but still good, especially when u start making high damageThe Swap seems abit exaggerated, with multiple enemies with unlimited spawns, all coming for u, and if u dun face them, u cant enter, meditate or even talk to characters so ye rlly annoying having Drowners after that dun stop spawningOverall a 8/10, great ending and im eager to play the 2nd game

												Pro's:- Great introductrion to the universe of The Witcher- Very "mature" contect, i.e. racism, sexuality and brutality- Great soundtrack- Exciting storyCon's:- Combat gets boring after a while- Controls are difficult, keymapping advised- Graphics are a bit out of date (lots of the same skins)Conclusion:If you would like to follow the entire Witcher story, this is a good place to begin. It gives you insight into the world and the story contains key-aspects that come back in the sequels. If you can't stand boring combat, or out-of-date graphics, start with The Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings. If not, play this one first.

content:
ber 14, 2016
												Despite the fact that this game didn't age very well, it's a solid game if you are curious to know how the Witcher games started.The combat mechanics are a bit weird and repetitive, but they are also kind of satisfying, it feels good to complete the attack sequences and to switch fighting stances to better adjust to the situations.Alchemy in this game is amazing, you start the game knowing a few basic potions but you have to study the ingredients from books and bestiary entries before you can harvest them, you can either buy the books from merchants or get them for free by completing certain quests, it feels immersive. When you're brewing a potion, which you can only do while meditating, there's this mechanic where you can add an extra ingredient to your potion and it gains one of three extra effects, adding some extra tactical elements.Questing is ok, but there's A LOT of going back and forth around the same areas and gets tiring very soon, to me this is the biggest flaw in this game. If you can handle this then by all means buy it, it's a great game.

												Even though a game that doesn't manage to get away with the "Amnesia Story" without a few critics noticing that, The Witcher manages to uphold the bar for a decent story where morality actually maters. No, there's no big morality bar telling you whether what you do leads you to being Mother Theresse or Satan. There's actually an inticant way of making it work in the long run, a concequence for your action that was done way long ago(hopefully you didn't forget about it). There's no boring conversations, the combat is solid enough(hard to belive it's the Aurora engine from Neverwinter Nights 2). The whole theme features a nice slavic mythology on a pretty big level with a lot of lore and such. Definetely worth buying if one is looking for a more mature experience.

												The Witcher tells a very solid and interesting story that gonna immerse you into its world as you play as Geralt of Rivia, the White Wolf. It is filled with interesting characters and companions. The game feature multiple choices and this affects the flow of story and characters around you. The game may be dragged by its simplistic combat system, which is just clicking right mouse button. The graphic is muddy for an enhanced edition. Yet, the depth of the story and a vast amount of interesting personalities keeps me playing.8/10. Definitely a good start if you wanna know more about The Witcher's lore and universe.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2011
												Even though a game that doesn't manage to get away with the "Amnesia Story" without a few critics noticing that, The Witcher manages to uphold the bar for a decent story where morality actually maters. No, there's no big morality bar telling you whether what you do leads you to being Mother Theresse or Satan. There's actually an inticant way of making it work in the long run, a concequence for your action that was done way long ago(hopefully you didn't forget about it). There's no boring conversations, the combat is solid enough(hard to belive it's the Aurora engine from Neverwinter Nights 2). The whole theme features a nice slavic mythology on a pretty big level with a lot of lore and such. Definetely worth buying if one is looking for a more mature experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												I loved this game back in 2007, before a lot of patches made it better, I love it today, when some of its parts are very outdated. It's still an amazing adventure in a truly unique world with great story, witty dialogue and slavic mythology. Though, if you play it in English, it will lose some of its charm (note, I recommend playing it with Polish voice acting even if you leave text in a language you do understand).Even without some amazing mods (Full Combat Rebalance is almost a must for more fun play), which can make the rather annoying fighting much more fun, this game still holds up. The animation might be stiff, some events look visually silly, but there's enough amazing stuff happening for your imagination to fill the blanks and see what the game wanted to show, instead of what it actually shown at times.The main draw of the game is a story, so if you find gameplay lacking, fighting frustrating due to silly bugs that plagued Aurora engine (and a lot of BioWare games based on it), just don't feel bad, switch to easier mode, install the FCR mod (the fights will actually end faster with it) and enjoy the witchering adventure at it's best.And no, you don't need to know the lore or read the books before starting the game, in fact, some of it is more interesting to experience before reading the books, as books will undoubtedly colour your choices in the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												The Witcher - is one of the few modern (well, almost modern) 3rd person RPGs that really do their job properly. This game is not about levelling your character or killing tons of creatures with one swing of your sword. It's about playing o role - a ROLE playing game. You play as a witcher, a mutant that kills beasts. It's based on famous books series by Andrzej Sapkowski. Since you are a mutant, not every person likes you. More of that, you always have to chose how to behave, whos side to take. It's a first game by polish studio CD Project RED, so it's not brilliant, but you immediately forget about all it's cons when you start playing because a rare game can get you suck a real roleplay experience, such dark fantasy world, where everything is corruted, dark and still people survive and see bright things.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Let me start by saying: Please do not buy the game expecting gameplay or graphics too similar to Witcher 2 or 3! This game is quite a bit older than the two others, and has a different style. HOWEVER! What this game has going for it is another strong story and a lot of atmosphere. This is what the company got right even in this first game. It is obvious that the team truly loves the source (the books and stories) and the world and story in this game, IMO, is VERY immersive.The playstyle is quite different, just like the graphics. It reminds me a bit more of Diablo, as it's click-to-move. You have different stances which you switch with keys, according to what you are fighting. Of course, alchemy and signs are in this game as well, as they are just of a trademark of the character as the two swords are. The game is showing it's age, as the graphics are of course not comparable to the later games, and it's quite interesting to compare the mechanics of the games, and see how the series developed. But even though this game has weaknesses and will feel VERY different compared to the later ones (total readjustment especially regarding combat), it still has tons of atmosphere and, as I said, a fascinating story. It's actually quite impressive how much the (back then) small company put into this game. If you don't mind the fact that the game is a bit older and therefore is very different regarding graphics and playstyle, if you care about the characters (of course, many of the beloved characters from the stories and the other games appear here, for example Triss and Vesemir) and the story, you might find yourself quite immersed, and if you are willing to adjust to the very different movement and combat, you might enjoy it a lot. I sure did!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
												A unique role-playing game that is a rarity these days. Developed by a Polish company and is based on the book with the same title written by a Polish author called Andrzej Sapkowski. You play as Geralt, a mutant hunter who is specialised in fighting and slaying monsters. At the beginning of Geralt's story he does not remember much - he's found unconscious and is taken to the witchers' hideout. The establishment, then, is attacked by a group of bandits known as the Salamander - although defending the castle is a success, the witchers are unable to stop the bandits from stealing their precious mutagens. Geralt and his fellow witchers, therefore, set out to find where the gang is hiding and of course to take back what is rightfully theirs.Some notable elements that characterises Witcher and makes it different from other RPGs:--- Controlling Geralt is very easy. The game offers you several camera perspectives, in fact, even the input device can be changed: focus can be on the mouse solely or you can use the combination of the keyboard and mouse - whichever is your preference.--- During combat timing is very important. The game being hack-and-slash requires you to hit enemies several times. This, Geralt does automatically, but following the hit of his blade you can have a follow-up click with your mouse - if your timing is perfect Geralt does make a follow-up cut which is stronger and deadlier. In addition to this the game employs 3 combat styles. Larger enemies require the strong style: Geralt carefully times each hit and while they are slower they result in a heavier slash. Faster enemies simply avoid your attacks but changing to the fast style enables you to hit them. And if your are surrounded you need to use the group style.--- Beside the styles and the timing you should be careful with the material your weapon is made of. While steel-made swords are perfect against human beings and some of the monsters you encounter there are many supernatural beings in the Witcher's world you can only wound with a silver-made sword. And here come those that made me like the game a lot:--- Choices: Yes, yes, this is common. You decide to help or you simply let people die. Right? No! Witcher does not indicate what will happen once a decision is made. Unlike Mass Effect, here there are no indicators and nobody tells you whether it is good or bad what you'll attempt to do. In certain cases both decisions you can make will result in the death of someone - you need to decide which is "better" or you simply need to pick A) so that in your next playthrough you can go with option B. --- Alchemy: A very important part of the game! There are severals types of plants / herbs out there you need to collect. You can then use these at fireplaces to create potions that either make you stronger or grant you an extra ability (e.g. seeing in dark places). Interestingly, all of these poison Geralt to a certain degree - your toxicity level increases and eventually you need to rest or drink another potion that neutralises the adverse effect of these drinks. The more scrolls you find the more potions are available - you can also experiment if you have the time. It should be noted that Geralt is mainly a warrior. You have some spells called signs but they are nothing special. So, in your next playthrough you cannot have a significantly different build - you can experiment, for sure, but the value lies in Witcher's world. And this world is huge. I like how the game starts filling up your Glossary - a menu similar to the codex in the Dragon Ages series containing all kinds of entries explaining the world to the gamer. Also, while fistfighting is rather easy and boring the drinking and dice-poker mini games are excellent and make the game quite funny!I finished the game in 50+ hours and pretty much completed everything I could. I read the game's wikia pages parallelly and found that I'd missed some missions and if I remember correctly the game has at least 2 endings. So there you go: over 100 hours and this is only for 8 bucks! In addition to this, it comes in the form of a so-called Enhanced Edition that offers a lot of extras such as making-of videos and other campaigns. Plus, the game looks quite good for being released in 2007!Overall, Witcher is a unique RPG. If you are fan of the genre and finished multiple playthroughs in Dragon Age then do head for the store page as this game must be in your basket!

content:
4, 2016
												The first Witcher is a game which differs from Witcher 2 or 3 very much. First of all: combat relies on sequences of attacks which needs pressing the mouse button in the correct time. I understand that some people might not like it, I liked it very much, especially when you unlock more sequences, fights can get quite spectacular. The skill tree is also different comparing to Witcher 2. Every level in experience grants you some skill points which you can assign to strenght, durability, Aard, Igni (sort of magic spells) or to some of the combat styles. There is quite amount of sidequests to complete, maybe not a lot, but still quite a few. They are fun, but some requires bactracking which can be boring. Still, the story is very nice and your decisions have an impact in the future events. Soundtrack is astonishing, in my opinion way better that in the Witcher 2. It really lets you feel the atmosphere of poor countrysides, filthy city or the horrific tombs. I do not know how well english voice actors did theirs jobs, but in the polish version of the game they did suprisingly well.Although I think that characters are quite interesting they do not have much to say so they do not stand out from the rest of the NPCs. I noticed some minor graphics bugs but nothing too serious. To sum up, i think that The Witcher is a very good game with great plot, music and combat system, but it is specific type of game and I will understand a person who will not agree with me.

content:
31, 2016
												I've never listened about the Witcher saga until 2015 when I saw TW3 was about to be released. I felt curiosity for it and after looking for info I liked it: ahuge RPG and with a very rich story. Although I had in mind the idea of buying it I didn't do it at the end 'cause a couple of months before there were steam sales on The Witcher 1 and 2 :D 90% ones so I immediately grabbed my wallet and paid the few bucks they costed.I loved this first one for ALL of it. The story, the characters you come across with, the music, the combat system (not dynamic or stressful at all, just clicking at the right moment, cast some Signs and swallowing a couple of potions. The toxicity factor also was extremely interesting and realistic (?) ). The plot twists, the all-the-same-NPCs, their realistic quotes, the books and the info you could get from them to learn more about the Witcher's world, the side quests, the witcher contracts that made me feel like a real witcher though were boring and poorly paid, ALL OF IT was completely worth and enjoyable and I do not regret playing it. Just buy it and be astonished.

content:
ry 28, 2016
The Witcher: A True RPG ExperienceThe Witcher is a layered and lengthy gaming experience. Based on the book series of the same name written by Andrzej Sapkowski, the game works to expand on the mythology of the character. The question always rides in "is it worth playing The Witcher 1 to play The Witcher 2 or 3?" While not necessary to enjoy the later installments, it will greatly enhance your gaming experience as you will be savvy to the lore that precedes Assassins of Kings and The Wild Hunt. The GameNow on to the game itself; it is long. It can be "rushed" but that does not entail a quick romp through what the game has to offer. There's preparation involved, just like a real Witcher, and using the game's multitude of mechanics is imperative to success in the game. While this can make for a frustrating experience, it also makes it doubly rewarding. The exhaustive use of oils, bombs and alchemy will serve to make you more capable in taking on the many enemies, monsters and specters you will encounter.The game itself, for being a bit older, has held up well in terms of narrative and by extension, voice acting and the like. Graphics are notably dated, but don't detract from the overall experience, and sometimes even add to the atmosphere. The most damaging aspect of this game is its combat which can be chalked up to timed clicking. It can be very frustrating and sometimes completely unresponsive. Understandably, this may turn some players away, but it should not completely ruin the game experience. It might cause some ragequits and make you think this game is a pile of rubbish, but when you finally get past that horrendous Zeugl or Wraith or Grandma, the satisfaction is unparalleled.  To also emphasize the most drawing aspect of the game, the use of "choice" is very well executed in The Witcher. Your words and actions have real consequences and truly shape your game. This type of storytelling is seen from time to time, but not always done as well as The Witcher has managed. The ability to see the effect Geralt has on the world of the Witcher is truly worth playing the game, if only for that very reason. The ConsUnfortunately, the game suffers from some poor design choices and very long and very dull sections that can hinder the narrative's momentum (and your interest). Chapters II, and by extension, III are the breaking points of the game -- if you can get past them, you'll get to the real meat of the game and it will become far more enjoyable and better paced. The Temple Quarter and Swamps also present poor environmental design which demand a lot of running around and ridiculous barricades that only serve to slow your progress. This ultimately adds unnecessary length to the game and can become fairly boring and repetitive quickly.   However, the game's relative length is entirely up to the player. If you desire to experience all the game has to offer, you're in for a long haul, topping 60+ hours, easily. A casual playthrough, with some side quests and exploration will clock in at 30+/- hours, and I'm sure if you really rush it, you could get away with 15-20+/- hours. SummaryThe Witcher is a fantastic narrative experience that while sometimes very lengthy, demands you immerse yourself fully in its lore and atmosphere to enjoy it completely, and once done, is a truly amazing experience. Its dated gameplay could see some players walking away, but if you can push through some of the more mundane parts and questionable design elements, the game is very rewarding. While it is not the best of games and not a prerequisite to playing The Witcher 2 & 3, it is wholly worth experiencing. And at its current price, you could do far worse.  IMPORTANT HOT TIP FOR 500 ORENSSave often. It'll save your hide more than you can imagine.

content:
er 1, 2016
												It's remarkable, genuinely remarkable to me that the Witcher 3, one of the best RPGs in recent memory, was a continuation of this game. And before I say anything else (because frankly, most of what I can say about this from a critical perspective is negative) I would recommend this game, for two main reasons: first, it's actually got a very intriguing and deep lore behind it, and the gameplay works off that lore, with dozens of enemies that require unique tactics and adaptability to defeat, making the Witcher a game that really rewards you for preparing before wading into a fight. Secondly, the third instalment is an incredible game and playing this through has only enhanced my appreciation for what the third game told me.I had a disk copy of this game for about six years before I bought it on steam, and the only reason I even have it in digital form is that due to a steam offer, buying all three witcher games was bizarrely cheaper than just buying the third one. When I first got it, the game became one of those things you stop playing for about a year, go back to it wondering why you ever stopped playing, and then remember instantly as soon as you start a new game. I'll get the negatives out of the way first: the game is about as unpolished as you can get without being unfinished; awkward voice acting, convoluted character motivations, and a combat system that's faaaar too big for its boots. To name a few instances, I spent far too long on what should have been evenly matched fights because when you enter a new area, enemies are able to react and swarm you about three seconds before you regain control of your character, and with the game's janky collision where the witcher seems more than content to wait for his axe wielding foe to step aside and let him pass rather than his dodge function actually moving him past the enemy, you're virtually unable to escape such situations. Additionally, good luck dealing with situations where you need to use multiple weapon types, since Geralt will be in at least twenty six pieces by the time he's switched weapons.But I'd still recommend this game. Because, while we can take it for granted today with its HD, triple A, fantastically polished descendant at the very top of its game, the Witcher 3 may never have been made without CD Projekt Red having the balls to do something different. And by god was this different. One of the few fantasy worlds where your character feels like both a blank slate on account of his memory loss, giving you the excuse to react to situations in your way, and also like you're a part of the world because of how people react to you because you're a witcher. And yes, I could harp on the combat mechanics for a long long while, but this bizarre, off the wall system paved the way for something beautiful years later. It's the type of game that will entertain you if you have an attachment to the Witcher series because of the books or later games or if you're an RPG fan. If either of those apply to you, I'd give it a try.

content:
y 11, 2016
												I can't make up my mind whether to thumbs up this or thumbs down it. I keep changing my mind.When I first got it. I was shocked by the dreadful controls, the lurchy, awkward, 45 degree granularity camera angles. The strange inability to jump. Being unable to drop off ledges, or drop off an in game height of more than a millimeter. If there is a brick or a pebble or an insect on your path, or just a drunken lardarse blocking a doorway. You're out of luck, you cannot procede. Parkour in this game is absolutely zero, it is totally unforgiving. Forget jumping over gates. You've got to walk 10-20km around to get somewhere 2 inches away.Then after about 30 minutes swearing at the sword controls, wondering why I was completely unable to hit anything, consulting with the controls menu several times, and restarting the game 3 times in case it was some bug, i eventually after much googling found you have to hold the ♥♥♥♥ing button to slash someone. Okay, from then on the game got a little bit easier, but there were still things that were annoying, you don't learn about anything until after you've killed a main character, and that's soo frustrating. The map is completely ♥♥♥♥ing useless. It took me 20-30 minutes and a main character death of the bar maid to work out that there's a second map option. What is the large map even for?! Why was the barmaid i was supposed to escort home refusing to tell me where she lived? Why when i approached her and engaged in dialogue does she say nothing, when all the other characters have indepth dialog trees? The game was growing on me upto this point. But then something terrible happened. I enabled fistfighting powerups. And that totally broke my game. It was completely and totally impossible to throw a punch of any kind, if you did because you had to hold the mouse button to throw the punch, the powerup would come on, preventing you from throwing the punch. God knows how the powerup works, because after dying repeatedly to weaklings in pub fights, i still to this day don't understand how they work. Some clue, would be nice with these things. All i can do is throw pathetic punches at the ground where spotty nerds with no muscels, no life and no fighting ability capitolise on my total inability to do anything but lurch around throwing punches at the ground, unable to get out the way, or do anything really. I mean the fighting is broken anyway, but that just breaks it so you can't even exploit the game bugs to win.With several main characters dead I tried to restart the game off an old game save repeating 6 hours of gameplay because of in game faults. Seriously, you have been warned. Fist fighting powerups are just horribly broken. So I go back and try and save the woman who died due to the game's poor design. That's when it happened again. Yes. And a third time. And a fourth. The game isn't on difficult mode. It's on easy. The problem is control. Control over the character. Control over the camera angles, control over the flow of gameplay, control over upgrades. There is no control. You see some missions happen at night. This woman comes out and needs rescuing at night. Unfortunately it occurs at the exact same time as a different mission you are on which involves glow in the dark dogs to be ♥♥♥♥ing everywhere. So unsurprisely she turns into dog food. I can't work out if there is any way to restore her health, the game is obtuse in that regard, you've got to read the mind of some developer who was smashed on crack when he designed this thing. Because the exhaustive information in the menus are only there to tell you about magic. If you want to actually know how to use the magic, then you're out of luck kiddo, you're best bet is to randomly click on buttons until by chance you the right combinations or you click on something that is fatal to your game's progression and you wont realise you've screwed up until several hours later when some game feature you've been using for hours goes ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and malfunctions and you die. Repeatedly. Without knowing why.So now I have to redo the first 6 hours of the first level again. Because some developer somewhere didn't think to disable concurrent missions. In my opinion that is a bug. A serious one. I know of no other game like this that allows concurrent game missions - for exactly this reason. ♥♥♥♥ this. Bad controls. Bad camera angles. Bad design of level and mission structure. No feature to postpone or disable missions. Game breaking skills tree. This game is just there to completely ♥♥♥♥ you off. How is it possible to know in advance that you've activated a bad combination of missions? Oh wait you can't. You just have to do missions ONE AT A TIME. String out the entire game for the rest of your life. Get to some point where the game 99% complete and find out that something you altered in the first 10% has broken that final 1%. This is what the game is like. Thanks, but no thanks.And that's the problem with this game. It's a lovely game, and you want to sit down and play it bugs and all because it's such a nearly perfect game and it's immersive and charming. But each and everytime you get into it, some game breaking bug jumps up out of nowhere and nuts you in the balls. Nobody really sat down and thought it out, or tested it, or patched the problems. I don't like giving thumbs down. But some games utterly deserve it. This is one of those games that if you play it, it's just going to make you angry.The reason it makes you so angry is because if it was a bad game you could just walk away, but it isn't a bad game, it's a great game with awful annoying issues that just totally ruin the players enjoyment.I don't want to be angry. I want to relax. Games should always be easy to control and flowing, the difficulty should come from problems that need solving within the game. The game should not be difficult because you have crippling design problems and bugs and controls which decided to go the opposite way to the rest of gaming history.I will probably continue playing this because it's such a charming game, despite the "idiosyncracies", and it definitely does the "je ne sais quoi" which defines a classic life changing game. Who knows maybe it's the awkward control and camera angles and the crazy haphazard mission layout that we love about it...I'll thumbs up I guess. God only knows why...

content:
24, 2014
												If you want start playing the Witcher series, but not sure which one to start with, PLAY THIS ONE FIRST. No matter what anyone says, this game is a game not to be missed. (It's like, $2 during a sale anyway)Because I saw The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt coming soon, I decided to start this series. At first I thought, "Oh, I should just start with the second one. This game is too outdated anyway." However I convinced myself to play this game first. So I did. And I'm very glad I did.When the game starts, Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher, has mysteriously reappeared from the dead. He was taken into Kaer Morhen, a Witcher stronghold where they guard the secrets of creating a Witcher.After a period of time, Kaer Morhen is attacked by unknown bandits, and the secrets are stolen. It's up to Geralt of Rivia, the famed White Wolf, to retrieve them and take revenge.The game takes place after the end of all the novels of the Witcher novels written by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski, so you needn't worry if you hate reading. However, if you love reading like I do, I recommend reading the books too as they add lots of depth and background to the characters. The story is easily the best part of the game. Chapter 1 is really a chore to get through, but at Chapter 2 it starts to pickup, and at Chapter 3 it really starts to get interesting. There are 5 chapters total, with a prologue and epilogue. The game really makes you feel like you're in the world, with some NPCs you pass by calling you a freak and some you used to know surprised of your revival. The voice acting is superb. Most choices in the game have great impact, and you have 2 sides to choose from, or neutral. (I recommend the neutral path cause it's more true to the novel Geralt) The devs don't lie when they say, "NO GOOD AND NO EVIL - ONLY CHOICES AND CONSEQUENCES." The game is pretty long too; I skipped all of the notice board quests and did a large amount of sidequests (I got all the cards too...) and I clocked in at around 30 hours. If you weren't rushing like I was, or a completionist you may clock in at even more hours, like 50. The amount of content in the game is pretty large.For graphics, there's not much to say. This game is fairly old now, but it doesn't look TOO bad. Just don't look at the later games, cause the devs really went leaps and bounds on the graphics. Personally, I thought they were bearable, but if you just finished playing a more modern game, you're eyes might get sore.Now the gameplay. The reason that made this game get mixed reviews from critics, I'd say. The combat isn't your typically hack and slash. Instead, you attack and wait for Geralt to do some moves, and then attack again and specific intervals. This system is extremely clunky and annoying, and there were many unnecessary difficulties and frustrations. By the end of Chapter 2 though, I would bet you would get used to it by then. I didn't viciously HATE the system like some, but I definitely disliked it a fair bit. I thought it's less of a glorified quicktime event as many say, but more of like a "automated hack and slash". Regarding music, I think this game's soundtrack is pretty good. I even enjoy listening to it when studying or whatever else. I really love it when games have excellent music. It wasn't a masterpeice as say, The Legend of Zelda's soundtrack, and some tracks get repetitive, but some others like Vizima Trade Quarter and Chapter 3 Inn music really stood out for me. And hearing it's "main theme" in the Witcher 3 trailers gets me pumped. All in all, I really recommend this game.I cannot emphasize enough though, play this one first. Pick it up, and play through chapter 1 and a bit of 2. If you can't play it anymore cause you don't like it, I won't judge. But don't let this one pass by without at least a look.7/10, for outdated nuisances (like loading screen immersion breaks, lack of the ability to jump, subpar graphics by today's standards and invisible walls), a really bad combat system, and a painful, hard to get into beginning.

												The Witcher is a captivating series based on a series of Polish books. It took some time for the series to gain momentum, but this games sequel was a resounding success and the third and final game is set to be the greatest game of all time.If you can get past the prologue and the combat system you'll begin to really love this game.I was committed to completing this game and I had a lot of trouble getting started, I nearly gave up on this game at that point. The game has very bad mechanic but it will grow on you with continued use, and these mechanics have divided audiences between both hating the game and loving it. Once you've adapted to these mechanics, you can emerse yourself in the story and you really will love this respectably long game - it will hype you for the sequel and the sequels sequel prior to its release.The decisions made in the game will affect the plot throughout the entire trilogy, so make sure you choose the moral choices you'd actually choose in the situation, otherwise you could play the entire trilogy to a particular moral style.It's one of the longer games I've played and I normally don't really like role playing games, and I would play this again without question.

content:
ry 28, 2016
The Witcher: A True RPG ExperienceThe Witcher is a layered and lengthy gaming experience. Based on the book series of the same name written by Andrzej Sapkowski, the game works to expand on the mythology of the character. The question always rides in "is it worth playing The Witcher 1 to play The Witcher 2 or 3?" While not necessary to enjoy the later installments, it will greatly enhance your gaming experience as you will be savvy to the lore that precedes Assassins of Kings and The Wild Hunt. The GameNow on to the game itself; it is long. It can be "rushed" but that does not entail a quick romp through what the game has to offer. There's preparation involved, just like a real Witcher, and using the game's multitude of mechanics is imperative to success in the game. While this can make for a frustrating experience, it also makes it doubly rewarding. The exhaustive use of oils, bombs and alchemy will serve to make you more capable in taking on the many enemies, monsters and specters you will encounter.The game itself, for being a bit older, has held up well in terms of narrative and by extension, voice acting and the like. Graphics are notably dated, but don't detract from the overall experience, and sometimes even add to the atmosphere. The most damaging aspect of this game is its combat which can be chalked up to timed clicking. It can be very frustrating and sometimes completely unresponsive. Understandably, this may turn some players away, but it should not completely ruin the game experience. It might cause some ragequits and make you think this game is a pile of rubbish, but when you finally get past that horrendous Zeugl or Wraith or Grandma, the satisfaction is unparalleled.  To also emphasize the most drawing aspect of the game, the use of "choice" is very well executed in The Witcher. Your words and actions have real consequences and truly shape your game. This type of storytelling is seen from time to time, but not always done as well as The Witcher has managed. The ability to see the effect Geralt has on the world of the Witcher is truly worth playing the game, if only for that very reason. The ConsUnfortunately, the game suffers from some poor design choices and very long and very dull sections that can hinder the narrative's momentum (and your interest). Chapters II, and by extension, III are the breaking points of the game -- if you can get past them, you'll get to the real meat of the game and it will become far more enjoyable and better paced. The Temple Quarter and Swamps also present poor environmental design which demand a lot of running around and ridiculous barricades that only serve to slow your progress. This ultimately adds unnecessary length to the game and can become fairly boring and repetitive quickly.   However, the game's relative length is entirely up to the player. If you desire to experience all the game has to offer, you're in for a long haul, topping 60+ hours, easily. A casual playthrough, with some side quests and exploration will clock in at 30+/- hours, and I'm sure if you really rush it, you could get away with 15-20+/- hours. SummaryThe Witcher is a fantastic narrative experience that while sometimes very lengthy, demands you immerse yourself fully in its lore and atmosphere to enjoy it completely, and once done, is a truly amazing experience. Its dated gameplay could see some players walking away, but if you can push through some of the more mundane parts and questionable design elements, the game is very rewarding. While it is not the best of games and not a prerequisite to playing The Witcher 2 & 3, it is wholly worth experiencing. And at its current price, you could do far worse.  IMPORTANT HOT TIP FOR 500 ORENSSave often. It'll save your hide more than you can imagine.

In my opinion that is a bug. A serious one. I know of no other game like this that allows concurrent game missions - for exactly this reason. ♥♥♥♥ this. Bad controls. Bad camera angles. Bad design of level and mission structure. No feature to postpone or disable missions. Game breaking skills tree. This game is just there to completely ♥♥♥♥ you off. 												If you want start playing the Witcher series, but not sure which one to start with, PLAY THIS ONE FIRST. No matter what anyone says, this game is a game not to be missed. (It's like, $2 during a sale anyway)Because I saw The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt coming soon, I decided to start this series. At first I thought, "Oh, I should just start with the second one. This game is too outdated anyway." However I convinced myself to play this game first. So I did. And I'm very glad I did.When the game starts, Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher, has mysteriously reappeared from the dead. He was taken into Kaer Morhen, a Witcher stronghold where they guard the secrets of creating a Witcher.After a period of time, Kaer Morhen is attacked by unknown bandits, and the secrets are stolen. It's up to Geralt of Rivia, the famed White Wolf, to retrieve them and take revenge.The game takes place after the end of all the novels of the Witcher novels written by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski, so you needn't worry if you hate reading. However, if you love reading like I do, I recommend reading the books too as they add lots of depth and background to the characters. The story is easily the best part of the game. Chapter 1 is really a chore to get through, but at Chapter 2 it starts to pickup, and at Chapter 3 it really starts to get interesting. There are 5 chapters total, with a prologue and epilogue. The game really makes you feel like you're in the world, with some NPCs you pass by calling you a freak and some you used to know surprised of your revival. The voice acting is superb. Most choices in the game have great impact, and you have 2 sides to choose from, or neutral. (I recommend the neutral path cause it's more true to the novel Geralt) The devs don't lie when they say, "NO GOOD AND NO EVIL - ONLY CHOICES AND CONSEQUENCES." The game is pretty long too; I skipped all of the notice board quests and did a large amount of sidequests (I got all the cards too...) and I clocked in at around 30 hours. If you weren't rushing like I was, or a completionist you may clock in at even more hours, like 50. The amount of content in the game is pretty large.For graphics, there's not much to say. This game is fairly old now, but it doesn't look TOO bad. Just don't look at the later games, cause the devs really went leaps and bounds on the graphics. Personally, I thought they were bearable, but if you just finished playing a more modern game, you're eyes might get sore.Now the gameplay. The reason that made this game get mixed reviews from critics, I'd say. The combat isn't your typically hack and slash. Instead, you attack and wait for Geralt to do some moves, and then attack again and specific intervals. This system is extremely clunky and annoying, and there were many unnecessary difficulties and frustrations. By the end of Chapter 2 though, I would bet you would get used to it by then. I didn't viciously HATE the system like some, but I definitely disliked it a fair bit. I thought it's less of a glorified quicktime event as many say, but more of like a "automated hack and slash". Regarding music, I think this game's soundtrack is pretty good. I even enjoy listening to it when studying or whatever else. I really love it when games have excellent music. It wasn't a masterpeice as say, The Legend of Zelda's soundtrack, and some tracks get repetitive, but some others like Vizima Trade Quarter and Chapter 3 Inn music really stood out for me. And hearing it's "main theme" in the Witcher 3 trailers gets me pumped. All in all, I really recommend this game.I cannot emphasize enough though, play this one first. Pick it up, and play through chapter 1 and a bit of 2. If you can't play it anymore cause you don't like it, I won't judge. But don't let this one pass by without at least a look.7/10, for outdated nuisances (like loading screen immersion breaks, lack of the ability to jump, subpar graphics by today's standards and invisible walls), a really bad combat system, and a painful, hard to get into beginning.

content:
r 18, 2016
												It's not as flashy as the later games and might not have the same widespread appeal, but if you're a fan of the sequels, or just want an old-school yet approachable RPG to spend several dozen hours with, The Witcher is definitely worth considering.It's starting to show its age, and it was never a very big-budget game to begin with, but for a 2007 game running on a 2002 engine it's more than presentable.I'd say I did the majority of stuff there is to do, and the game took me 40 or so hours to beat. There's certainly replay value with the choices and leveling.The Witcher conveys the sense of "monster hunting" better than either of its sequels. The creatures are straight out of folklore as opposed to common fantasy, and the requirement of having to read books and learn about your targets is something you don't see in games very much at all.The potion system is still incredible.Combat is pretty much passive and I'd recommend playing on hard.The tone is markedly different from the later games. There's certainly gray morality, but it's not exaggerated as much, and feels more "organic," in a way. The story has a really unique feel, combining the feeling of a classical epic with subtle social commentary which the later games focus on more.Some of the dialogue, cutscenes, and such is silly, and I wouldn't call it a classic, but The Witcher is a great game and a very worthy start to the series. If you haven't done so, check it out.

												This has to be one of the best games I have ever played. I played it just last year, and in spite of the outdated graphical quality, it pretty much blew my mind. It took me roughly forty hours to finish the game (and I left out maybe a third of the side-quests) and it was a forty hours well-spent. And what honestly is the most impressive to me is the soundtracking. I haven't played a game before or since this one that is soundtracked as well. Overall, I'd say 10/10 for anyone who enjoys RPGs, or any kind of fantasy game.

												This review comes from me having played this when it came out in 2007, and beaten twice so my Steam hours don't do it justice.__________________________________________________________________________________________If you had ever played a role-playing game before The Witcher came out, chances are that most of the game involved people asking you to go places, deliver items, and kill things. Then this little beauty was born.After the Witcher 3 came out and caught everybody's attention, many people who haven't played the series end up asking the question "should I play the first two games in the series?". Inevitably, many people will recommend playing The Witcher 2: a great game with solid controls and outstanding visuals. And what visuals they were, able to bring the gaming rigs (at the time) to their knees. While I'd agree with all of that, I'd also add that everyone should play the first game, because I found it to be one of the best RPGs of all time. It is, through and through, a true RPG. One that focuses on choice and the resulting consequence, rather than character building etc.Usually in every conversation I have regarding The Witcher, someone always admits to quitting, usually due to the unique fighting mechanics or during the game's extensive swamp section. But because The Witcher is structured linearly, and it seems as though it was built that way, it results in a game that constantly gets better as the story progresses. The second act improves upon the first, the third improves upon the second and so on and so forth. Despite the game's initial awkwardness, it becomes apparent to the player that things are picking up and where a certain brilliance can be felt in the story. But it's the fourth act where the crescendo really occurs and is that which really makes The Witcher what it is, what it's meant to be. Every moment in the act is interconnected in some way. Every character seems to have a relationship with every other character. And each character has a little quest for you, which in turn will all lead back to the original quest. It's a beautiful thing really. Alina and Julian are getting married, but Alina's taking care of Alvin, who leads you to the local hermit, who takes you back to the Lady of the Lake, who wants you to kill a monster in a particular way, and on it goes.The thing about these quests is that they are different in regards to other RPGs. Tasked with killing things in order to obtain items is fine, but it's a simple approach to a more full-filling one that these side quests can offer. The Witcher recognises that these games aren't so much about the skills players choose, but the choices you make. Each choice leads to a different outcome. And these choices are generally based off the player's view on matters, or how they feel, which makes the whole experience that much more authentic.Of course The Witcher is not unique in this regard, but it can certainly serve as a more refreshing approach to how RPGs should be made. Convincing a ghost that she is, in fact, a ghost so as to help her pass on to the afterlife is not a quest that would be present in many games. Nor would a quest, such as the aforementioned, end with the main character participating in a poetic duel with a bard. The Witcher isn't the most beautiful game, with its wonky animations and the odd poor texture here and there, making it incomparable to its successor The Witcher 2. The more I played, however, the more I found myself sucked in. You end up learning that ignoring side quests is not an option. You just have to see more, play more, experience more. The Witcher shows us that there can be more to RPGs than just fighting.I, personally, thoroughly enjoyed the underlying themes in certain parts of the game.Act IV explores the different topics present in its story through the actions taken by the NPCs and the player. Two species with two different sides to the story. A ghost who isn't so much evil as it is misguided, and even in death it loves gambling so much that it tries to gamble for a human life. The monsters themselves seem to embody failed loves and desires. So much seems to be going on and somehow, through all the intricacy of the narrative, the clever role-playing ideas of the initial parts of the game are brought together in Act IV to form a cohesive statement about love and other things. Laying it all out, dissecting it, and examining it, resulting in a culmination of understanding. So go ahead, do yourself a favour and pick it back up if you haven't already. Beat the game, and possibly end up having one of the best roleplaying experiences of your life. From Act IV onward. Or not. I don't mind.Update 3/12/2016: I've just discovered the OST and Inspired by soundtrack that come with the game. Seriously, such value for money. When on sale, it's $1.50. Outstanding.

content:
30
You can say whatever you want but this game actually is a more Witcher game than any of the following one's are.                It has a much more deep atmosphere soaring around the dirty air of a northern kingdoms.                It has a much more deep and mystery and dramatic soundtrack that gives you a real feeling of medieval                                                                                              despair, sadness and fear.And the plot is not a common AAA movie story about someone trying to invade and destroy the human world (i mean it is in core but in detalis it's completely not), Witcher  tells you a bunch of a simple storylines about few characters trying to survive and success in the cruel world of Sapkowski. They are neither good or bad, they are just people, like all we are. It faces a lot of things like faith, greed, racism, politics, simple injustice of our lifes and our world.Witcher just shows the human vices but doesn't push you to make any conclusions. It presents the human world in grey colors where nothing could be good or bad, everything is just exists.Like a great story-teller, it just tells and nothing more.A lot of time passed and you might be frightened by the game graphics or combat mechanics but you still have to play it if you wanna call yourself a real RPG fan. Totally recommended.

content:
, 2016
												Great story and dialogue, as well as decent amount of attention to details. The Enhanced Edition will be part of the reason for that (there is only an occasionally cheesy grating line unlike other games...). There is room for more refinement but the settings and characters etc generally make up for that.Special mention to the romance in the game with lots of t&a and nice art....really great.  The game has some occasional issues in combat with the camera in tight spaces and some ability sync with clicks and keypresses like for dodging, generally not impactful to your enjoyment of the game. And load/save game menu latency can get obnoxious -1 for that and not being able to name save games.    The camera controls are good but inflexible and limited if you want some slight changes (such as sticky cameras-it will swing back) or a low angle. Important Notes: Some things such as the cards for romance might need you to check lists for if you are a completionist. These lists will be a potential spoiler to people who care about that.   Having seen lists of quests for completion after finishing chapters, I can say that it can be tricky to get everything in and done how you may want as there are no hints of consequences and lack of further dialogue options. If you plan to play through several times this is unnecessary since you can choose different options each play through. You will want to hold save games at certain points so that you can go back if you don't like the responses, and to take a different path if you don't want to start from scratch. If you are an explorer/details type you will probably get everything. The lag in loading directly correlates to the number of save games, so you can delete the saves from the directory that you don't need.Choosing difficulty: Easy is actually a very valid option if you want the story, since the dialogue and story is good. -1 for no Autorun....srsly not cool -_- ....you can click and hold  the mouse button and drag to move aroundChapters in swamp and C4 are slightly flat and drawn out compared to other scenes.

content:
y 17
												I had a great time with The Witcher. It's a game that I was always going to love, being a fantasy role playing game with a satisfying world and a LOT to do. It reminded me of Dragon Age: Origins, albeit with adult themes (the player is encouraged to have sex with pretty much every female character they meet) and a unique fighting system (which involves stringing together really impressive sword movements to take on both monsters and human opponents).It should be noted that The Witcher isn't a perfect game. The story is highly praised, but the "decisions" I was given along the way didn't always impact proceedings as much as I thought they would. There are also parts of the game where I felt the story was being forced forward, and I was becoming a bit of a passenger. My only other negative comment is that I was so overpowered by Chapter V that no enemy could possibly hurt me, making combat very predictable.Despite these flaws, I found myself totally sucked into The Witcher's world. The visuals are jaw dropping, particularly those sunsets near bodies of water, and the romantic storyline somewhat satisfying. Being a completist, i was determined to complete every side quest, stretching my play time out to close to 60 hours. A sign of how much I enjoyed that commitment is that I'm super keen to jump straight into The Witcher 2. I've heard it's even better, so who knows, perhaps Morrowind and Baldur's Gate II will finally have a challenger in the fantasy RPG genre. Time will tell...

content:
er 6, 2013
												I'll keep this short and sweet because I think the majority of people that played The Witcher did so in order to get some backstory for preperation for The Witcher 2 & 3, thats just how I feel about it because I suppose thats the purpose of my playthrough because what it comes down to is the game alone isn't very delightful on its own but its not terrible either. I suggest playing it before going at The Witcher 2 so you have an idea of whats going on, plus it will make The Witcher two more enjoyable.The Witcher is a great RPG with anywhere from 50-80 hours of gameplay depending on how you want to take it along with choices to make that effect the story down the road and the game doesn't hold your hand. Minus chapters 2 and 3 (due to their watered down quests that seem to go on forever and the boring environments) out of 5 chapters along with a Prologue and a Epilogue the game is pretty fun and entertaining. Combat in the game turns off a lot of people right off the bat, I say give it a chance because once you get used to it you'll feel more intune to the way it works and you possibly may even enjoy it. For those who want to take on the hard difficulty, prepare to possibly rage due to a few boss fights and a few other silly encounters that are just plain unfair, unfourtunatly. The voice acting in the game is decent but often times laughable and the animations minus some of the combat animations are just plain silly. Character models are reused frequently as well throughout the game which was just plain lazy. All in all I'd say pick this one up even if its for a quick runthrough if you are planning on playing The Witcher 2 and 3.

content:
y 13
												WARNING:  OPINIONS ON THE INTERENET ARE FREE TO COMMENT! DON'T LIKE WHAT I HAVE TO SAY? DON'T READ IT.Alright where to begin.  First off the controls.  Geralt is hard to manuevre and control, this is most prevelent in combat, where it could take a long time between when the button is pressed and when the sword is swung.  This type of unresponsive control make me furious.  I don't want instant gratification, but reliable combat tactics.  Next, healing.  Healing during combat is impractical and a waste of time.  As you first need to select the item, and then watch Geralt drink the potion, all the while taking enemy hits, they won't for you.  The healing is also slow, and you can die before your potion finishes healing you.  Let's put it like this, when Dark Souls is considered fair compared to this; you know you have a design flaw.  This doesn't upset me, surprisingly.  This was CD Project Reds first game, they wanted to make a game world like the books of the Witcher, and succeeded.  But they didn't think about about what there mechanics stated to the player, that was their f&@# up.  Now they have since apologized for this misgrievence (in my opinion) with the other titles they have released in this trilogy.  If you want an example of bad top down design this is it right here and by all means play it for that.  But this really isn't worth it unless you want a headache.

												I first purchsed The Witcher about three years ago and gave it an honest go. I was not impressed. When it became available on Steam, I decided to once again give it a shot... I was once again disappointed. I have tried at least a dozen different times to get into this game - or to get any enjoyment out of it at all, really. However, over the many hours I have devoted to this game, I can honestly say that I have never had a single moment where I even began to like any part of it.I really wanted to get into this game (because of all the praise that seems to be constantly showered upon it), and I really did give it the best possible chance(s) that anyone could expect... But The Witcher is without a doubt one of the worst games I have ever had the unpleasant experience of playing. Every aspect of the game: Gameplay, Storyline, voice acting, etc., I found to be repugnant. The only recommendation I can offer is this: Do not get this game. Save yourself the disappointment that I had to endure every time I launched the game.

content:
r 4, 2016
												Pros:- Engaging story with non-obvious plot twists.- Excellent voice acting.- Choice-based story consequences.- Long adventure.- Good mix of spells/swords/crafting to keep you entertained.- Additional adventures included by devs and fans that add backstory. Neutral: - No controller support. - Ok background music.-Your decisions not only impact the story, but some lore-important side-quests will be closed off to you depending on what you choose to do/who you do or do not randomly run into in the cities.  There's no real way to experience all the quests without looking online the first time you play.  Some people may like this, but I don't feel this game merits a second play through just to pick up the remaining quests that complete the background lore.  There's often no warning you are completing a main-quest segment and will be leaving the area either, making it double challenging to find all the side-quests yourself.Cons:- Quite unstable for me on Windows 10.  It took me 5 in-game hours and many tweaks to get the crashing down from once every 20 mins to once every couple hours.  They should really re-think the two-hour return limit.- Many glitches and bugs.  There were times a character would try to hand me an important quest item, but my inventory was full, so the item just disappeared from the game.  The last chapter is totally unpolished and many of the mechanics don't work normally at the end of the game.  Several randomly bugged character textures as well, making me think a disfigured monster was attacking when it was actually a book merchant. - The swordplay is based around timed clicking.  This worked ok for Legend of Dragoon, but for an action RPG it feels a little silly.- The cities would often drop down to less than 30 fps in crowded areas, despite using far better hardware than was available when this game came out (using an i5 4590 and an R9 390).- The country-side part of the world feels big and empty, almost like this was supposed to be some kind of MMO but is void of life.- Some weapons and ability upgrades are not spaced out well and come FAR too late into the game so that most of them are pointless.- If you don't do things in the order the game was expecting, it can get confused and your journal will tell you to go somewhere that isn't where you are supposed to go.  The game catches up eventually when you pass certain checkpoints, but the story feels out of order and you wind up feeling like you are missing something.Conclusions: I view a "thumbs up" as saying this game is worth paying full price for.  If you want to play this game for the full Witcher experience, wait until it is on sale.  I view this game as skippable in the series.  Obviously I trudged through and I enjoyed the story, but the game was a mess to play with few solutions to common problems, and it single-handedly convinced me the refund window needs to be lengthened.

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6
												After hearing such good things about The Witcher III, I decided to finally finish a full playthrough of the earlier games before starting in on the third, but I guess it took at least one iteration of Witcher games for CD Projekt Red to actually figure out how to make a functioning game, because The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a pile of beta-stage crap.- Half of the "innovative" combat features are pointless and often do not work at all. Parrying, bleeding, precise hits, etc. are nothing more than behind the scenes numbers that offer nothing to enrich tedious combat (which consists of absolutely nothing more than swing format A, B or C). Dodging is slower than simply turning around and moving forward, and often enough Geralt is simply not allowed to dogde at all, for seemingly arbitrary reasons. When moving any other direction But forward, Geralt moves like an arthritis-wracked stump, lurching and dragging himself to his death (This gets worse when intoxicated, which is amusing because the game encourages drunk fighting via particular talents). Geralt will frequently refuse any input, disallowing motion, signs, combat, anything. Hit recognition seems to have been abandoned halfway through development, allowing Geralt to be hit across rooms, while opponents spend minutes at a time dodging every single combat style Geralt is allowed, even when knocked down or stunned.- A large amount of talents serve little to no purpose at all, only being taken because of the poorly conceived level system shoving enough talents in your face to unlock literally everything in almost no time at all. So much for strategic specialization. The same goes for potion-brewing, where even on the highest difficulty, where "potions are necessary" the lore-based toxicity system means you will use the same three (out of a few dozen) potions the entire game. The same goes for signs, with nothing past your first unlocked sign being of any use at all. All signs will often have no effect whatsoever, and no explanation is given as to why, not to mention arbitrarily "failing" every few attempts, and not being cast at all.- Sub-quests are the same tedious gather and kill quests RPG players have been tired of for years. Inventory is even more menial, being filled with dozens of random item variations (no doubt meant to be exotic, but instead are just a bother). You're forced to keep everything in order to satisfy the insanely random whims of NPCs desiring particular gifts, but are offered exactly zero in-game functions to track the inane demands of the masses.- Progression consists of new areas filled with old enemies, recolored and renamed. For being a monster-hunter, in a world that is, according to the story, more filled with monsters than ever, there are no more than about 12 species of monster in the entire game.To contrast what Projekt Red brags that their game is:"Enhanced inventory" forces collection to satisfy obscure quests, and storing items in the inn forces you to complete a quantity slider for every single item withdrawn. Red boasts superior item organiztion, but inn storage has absolutely no management options, and does not sort item categories at all, giving you a jumbled, small-fonted mess."Technical improvements" that list combat responsiveness improvements make me shudder to think how slow the game was beforehand. Input lag for signs and dodging is so long that it makes them liabilities in combat as opposed to boons."Character differentiation system" is a cute, bashful way of asking players if it's okay that they don't make new models, because this new enemy is two shades darker than the monster you fought last chapter, and that ♥♥♥♥♥s skirt is blue instead of green."Choose from over 250 special abilities" there are 226 talents, many of which are, as mentioned above, obselete. If you're going to blatantly lie in your bragging, at least make sure what you Did manage to cobble together is at least worth a damn.Later Witcher games might be good, I couldn't say. But skip this one and read a summary, because all playing this game is going to do is put you off the series by being a really garbage game.
