content:
ber 20, 2015
The Witcher ManBefore I begin, let me make a couple of things clear:I have not read the books, and this is not a book review. I'm also not here to make comparisons between the games and books. This is a game review only.If I could give this game a rating between thumbs up and thumbs down... say, like, a fist... I would do that, because my opinion is very mixed. But since I have more negative things to say than positive, I have to give it a thumbs down.I'm not out to "get" you if you enjoy this game, and what makes the world go 'round are differences in opinions. Do not take my criticisms as personal attacks on you and understand that reviews are opinions, and nothing will make me reassess mine. If you want to yell at me about my opinion and tell me how wrong I am and that I'm just some "simpleton", understand that nothing is going to change my mind, so you're only wasting your own time. This review is based on my own experiences with the game and how I reacted to it. Know that not everyone will experience a game the same way.What I liked about the game:1) In The Witcher, there are some pretty decent RPG elements. I like the leveling system, for one. I enjoy the fact that Strength, Dexterity, Endurance, and Intelligence have their own trees to pick from, and that you can also level up your weapons.2) The characters are amusing. Well, the male ones, anyway. The female ones are just sex dispensers with legs. I’ll get to that later.3) I love the alchemy. The starting potions are very “meh” but later you can craft much better ones and be practically unkillable. I also love picking up herbs to craft potions.4) The game on normal is just that: normal. Some games I’ve played on normal (especially fantasy RPGs) seem like the developers misunderstood what “normal” difficulty means.5) The brawling. It's stupid easy to do, so you can make some pretty decent cash off of it.6) I love the music. It fits a fantasy setting perfectly.7) The graphics in the Enhanced Edition are lovely and colorful, especially on the high graphics setting (Although it does seem to have a lot of stuttering and optimization issues).8) The gloomy, rainy weather.What I didn't like about the game:1) The dialogue is very dragging and leaves something to be desired. I'm all for story and role-playing, and I know this game was a book first, but there is a lot of talking, and much of the game's length is padded by it. What the characters sometimes say is very pretentious at times, and at other times, it tries too hard to be “edgy” by making everyone cuss all the time. I have nothing against swearing-- I swear like a sailor in real life-- but I don't do it half as much as this game did. You know that one kid in school who just learned to swear and thinks it’s the greatest thing ever? Yeah. That’s this game’s dialogue. And target audience.2) Female characters almost always have one of two purposes, or at times, both: to be rescued, or to be boned. No matter who the woman is, she will throw herself on Geralt (or whom I love to call "Greyalt") at the opportunity to screw him. I once talked to some elf girl who said she could teach me her language. “Cool!” I thought. “I want to learn elf language! That might come in handy for my character!” Next thing I know, her half-naked trading card flashes me out of nowhere and we’re screwing each other (or gelling together in the background, at least). What the hell? I wanted to learn elvish! I didn’t want to screw her! Then she wandered off and I never saw her again. Great. Pointless. Thank you for wasting my time. Many encounters I had with women were purely accidental out of my desire for completing all of the quests in the game.Despite this complaint, it is really good for a laugh seeing just how hard they were trying to up the sexiness of the game. People say the weirdest sexual things at really odd, inopportune moments, and it’s over-the-top, cheesy as all get out and hilarious. For example: "I can conjure up ♥♥♥♥♥♥s". Who says that, even if you are a sorceress?3) The combat. Yeah, you knew this was coming. This is the most common complaint about The Witcher, and it is 100% justified. It's extremely boring. Click. Wait for the cursor to turn orange. Click. Wait for it to turn orange again. Click. Again. Again. Again. It’s not that it’s hard, or complicated. It’s tedious and puts me to sleep. I have yet to try out Witcher 2, and I pray the combat is nothing like this one. One of the more tedious things about it is switching weapons for different enemies and situations, and how long it takes for him to pull out the next weapon. The game has to register that you made the change, so while you're waiting for Greyalt to pull out his other sword, you're standing there getting pummeled.4) There are no faster means of travel, and the maps are huge. This isn’t too big of a complaint, because I love massive environments. However, I still would have liked a mount of some kind to make it a little quicker.5) The quest tracking is a great feature, but sometimes it’s just plain wrong. It’ll tell you where a character might be rather than where they currently are.6) Those sub-weapons. They’re useless. Except the torch. I love the torch.7) The Signs aren’t good enough for me. Never used them, and I still completed the game just fine without them.8) Fetch quests. I eventually avoided taking contracts. I made money punching people instead. This didn't change the game's plot at all.9) Greyalt is a lousy protagonist. He’s a sarcastic ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that is always looking to start fights. I get that he’s supposed to be a “tough guy” or whatever, but he doesn’t seem to like or get along with anyone unless they open their legs for him. He talks in this really annoying Batman voice and never smiles. He's too busy brooding about which woman to be with.10) This contains semi-spoilers: Alvin (who I call "The Chipmunk"). There was no point to his existence other than to hook you up with one of two women and to pad the game with even more dialogue. You waste so much time playing around with this little runt, and nothing (interesting) ever comes of it. When the game came to its conclusion, I hadn't seen him for two chapters, and he never showed up again. It's possible that your connection with him is based on the path you chose... but should that really matter?11) Greyalt’s “amnesia” is conveniently gone when the plot calls for it.12) Drowners.Biggest Disappointment:This conclusion contains spoilersI have two: the romance elements, and Rayla.Simply put, Rayla was the only female character in the game I actually liked. However, she is never a romance option for you. Well, you can bone her once. But that doesn’t mean a thing. Because she dies immediately after. Twice. First by what’s-his-elfin’-name, and again by you, and you have no choice in this matter. The game saddles you with two possible perma-romance options: Shani (who I call "Yawni") and Triss ("Twits"). I didn’t like Yawni or Twits very much, but because I wanted to give Alvin a place to stay, I figured “here, Yawni, you take him. He’d be better off with you than Twits, who I swear is a psycho in disguise.” Yawni immediately attaches herself to you, even if you don’t want it, and begins to tell you she loves you and pretty much asks you straight up to marry her and have a little family with her. Um, holy crap? I didn’t want this. It seemed like the game refused to move forward unless you settled down with one of them. Well, I didn't like either of them. I called Yawni my "friend" and went about my business. Take that, game.

content:
y 11
												I just finished the game and loved it utterly. It took me approximately 72 hours of gameplay, but I like to do all secondary quests I can, so I'm sure it could be done much faster. I just want to recommend this game to all RPG fans out there. Unbelievable as it seems, I bought the game for 1,19 Euros at a sale. This is simply the most value I have ever got for my money EVER. The world has several different environments, and despite the aged game engine I found it very immersive to navigate the landscape. There is an enormous variety of creatures, potions, bombs, alchemical ingredients and NPCs to meet (and romance) and the depth and richness of Sapkowski's world shows through the ever growing entries in the in-game journal (with sections about characters, alchemical formulas, monsters, a glossary and, of course, quests). This is a fascinating, complex world in which hard decisions must be made, leading to different outcomes, but never being based in a simplistic "good vs evil" outlook. If you choose one given side, you will be making enemies on the other, even if you actually like both and understand their causes.The graphics are a bit aged and the combat system is rather clunky, but it is nevertheless a lot of fun. Geralt's skills evolve through a very diverse set of trees in which you can spend your gained experience after levelling, allowing for different builds and a lot of replay value.The music is also very good, and contributes strongly to the immersion.I definitely, without a doubt, recommend this game. This is a great RPG, a classic beyond any doubt, and a great introduction to the latter installments of the franchise. Unfortunately my laptop´s specs do not allow me to play the Witcher 2, but I already bought the Witcher 3 Game of the Year Edition on PS4 (TW2 was an XBox exclusive...) and I immediately felt at home, immediately encontering familiar characters, monsters and potions.

content:
y 21
												Story 9/10Gameplay 7/10Cons:-Crashes at times-Unfair Encounters w/ enemies or bosses-Stupid Camera Angles<-----[Extended Review]----->The Witcher: Enhacned Edition Director's Cut has a fine story to it that will carry over to the other witcher games, yet there are some frustrating parts to the game. I bought this game, along with the other witcher games, during the christmas steam sale at a cheap price, yet now I see it standing at it's full price $10 USD which I personally see a bit too high. The game really rotates around it's vivid story and the fact that you can transfer a saved game to Witcher 2 causing your choices to carry over, yet you must be able to wrap your head around what is going on. If you do not pay close attention to the story and the choices you make then you will end up pratically despising the game. Gameplay is where it really lacks and falls back greatly. You basically click on a target and choose one of three stances to take, each being effective against a certain foe, yet this gets real tedious at times even during boss fights. There will be times you face a quick agile character that will block your attacks constantly unless your using the swift stance, yet there will also be other enemies fighting that take little to no damage from your swift attacks. This gives the game some challenge so you don't just bulldoze through it, but there are just times where you will be in the middle of dialouge and your getting stabbed while still speaking (at other times you will end up facing a large squadron of foes in a compact space forcing you to dodge constantly or use group style in desperation to fend off the hordes). Im not going to judge the games graphics or audio since it was made back in 2008, but be ready to see some old timey graphics. Then there are camera angles that just will constantly bug you when speaking with a NPC. At times the NPC will look away from you and stare up into the sky while other times the camera is off centered and will only show you half of the NPC's face/body. Im truly giving this game a positive review since I be a personal Witcher fan and plan on reading the books to learn more about the game's lore. I reccomend this game to those who are fine with old timey graphics and unfair scernaios, but also seeking a intersting story to follow and learn. I give The Witcher: Emhacned Edition Director's Cut 8/10 Swallows

r 10, 2016
												I originally began playing this game just for the main story; to get the background for the withcer 2 and 3, the latter I have already beaten. The gameplay immediately stood out to me as being rather outdated, though surprisingly it grew on me. The story is the real star here though, I was completely infatuated with it by the beginning of the thrird chapter, so much so that I decided not only to restart the game, doing all the side quests, but also reading all the books and short stories, and boy, I was not disappointed by the books. I would highly recommend not only playing the first two games to completion before playing the third game, but also read the books before any of the games. It gave me an immense understanding of the characters and evenced referenced in the games. CD Projekt RED clearly understood the base material, and you will garner much more from the games if you do as well, not to mention, on their own they are extremely entertaining novels. This game is a true masterpeice that has (so far) stood the test of time phenomenally.

												The Witcher: Enhanced Edition Director's Cut isn't for everyone.  There are a lot of problems with this game: The combat is more comparable to Morrowind than Oblivion.  The mini map takes a while to get used to.  The graphics are not up to next-gen standards. You spend most of your time walking around the map instead of being fully productive. However, I still find myself dumping hours upon hours into this game. This game is a better RPG than witcher 2 and 3 in many ways.  The decisions you make matter and help drive the story foward.  You learn more about the chatacters from gwent cards and people you encouter during subsiqent games.  If you are a fan of the series and can tolerate a fairly lame combat sytem I would advise you to buy this game...But not until it goes on sale :-P

content:
9, 2016
												This may sound strange, but the first Witcher game is my favorite of the trilogy, and one of my favorite video games of all time. Despite what at first may feel clunky and awkward combat, animations, and voice acting; the Witcher remains one of the most compelling and charming RPGs ever made. My biggest complaint would only be the backtracking that becomes more and more commonplace towards the end of the game, but even the combat, which is often criticized by others, is enjoyable and engaging to me. The combat almost feels like a real time turn based RPG system. The world, the characters, and the choices are all excellent, and keep me coming back to beat the game over 4 times now.And I already can't wait for my next playthrough.
